title.narrative: Preservation of the Ancestral Knowledge of the Tikmu'un-Maxakali Indigenous People in the Mucuri Valley

description.narrative: The Tikmu'un-Maxakali people occupy one of Brazil's smallest indigenous territories and retain a complex and ancient knowledge system that includes their native language, traditional arts and crafts, songs, ceremonial practices, and specialized agricultural, fishing, and hunting techniques. This project involves the community-led documentation of multiple aspects of the Tikmu'un-Maxakali people's intangible heritage.

title.narrative: Conservation of the Early 19th-Century Valongo (Imperatriz) Wharf Archaeological Site in Rio de Janeiro

description.narrative: The Valongo Wharf is a tangible record of the largest port of landing of enslaved Africans in the Americas. This project directly supports the Embassys Integrated Country Strategy (ICS) Goal 3, advances the U.S.-Brazil Joint Action Plan to Eliminate Racial and Ethnic Discrimination and Promote Equality (JAPER), and showcases U.S. recognition of the United Nations 2015-2024 International Decade for People of African Descent.
